title: Understanding Fat Flux
content: The flow of fat entering and exiting a fat cell, which determines how much fat a person carries, is known as fat flux. Insulin has a significant influence on the net fat balance. Common strategies such as fasting and low-carb diets can aid in the liberation and oxidation of fat from fat cells.

title: Reducing Fat Mass
content: There are two main ways to reduce fat mass: reducing the total number of fat cells, typically done with liposuction, and shrinking the fat cells. However, there is a profound difference between losing fat via liposuction vs. through dietary & lifestyle interventions. The former is a cosmetic procedure, while the latter has cosmetic benefits but more importantly, a metabolic improvement.

title: Fat Flux and Fat Cells
content: If a fat cell gets larger, there is a net accumulation of fat in that cell relative to how much goes out of it. This can be understood through the concept of fat flux, which refers to the flux of fatty acids substrate into and out of a fat cell. This can help infer the behavior of that fat cell in response to that.

title: Fat Entry and Exit from Fat Cells
content: Fat enters a fat cell through two doors, which are ways that the fat cell gets fatter. On the other hand, there is an exit door, which is how the fat cell gets skinnier. The first door is how we bring fat into a fat cell, which involves triacylglycerides (TAG), three fatty acids onto a glycerol backbone, which is the way that we very efficiently store fat.

title: Lipoprotein Lipase and Insulin
content: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) facilitates the transport of triacylglycerides into the fat cell. Insulin is the strongest regulator of LPL and upregulates it. Insulin is a very anabolic hormone—a building hormone—so it’s anabolic to muscle and unfortunately anabolic to a lot of cancer and to a fat cell. Insulin is pro growth, and it wants to bring more of these fats in.

title: Glucose and Insulin
content: Insulin also drives the translocation process of a GLUT4 transporter. In a metabolically healthy person, there’s very little glucose that is being brought into the fat cell. But as a person becomes more and more insulin resistant at the muscle, we will see more of the glucose entering the fat cell via the GLUT4 transporter and then insulin is promoting lipogenesis. This means glucose can actually be turned in to fatty acids.

title: Fatty Acids and Triacylglycerides
content: There are two pools of fatty acids. One comes in via the triacylglyceride pool, meaning they’ve been broken down into their glycerol backbone and the fatty acids. Then there are fatty acids that are made de novo, hence the term de novo lipogenesis or DNL. These get re-esterified. While the glucose molecules are being broken down into fatty acid precursors, they’re also making glycerol. This process increases the density of the fat cell.

title: Fat Out of a Fat Cell
content: To get fat out of a fat cell, you have to break down the triacylglycerides or the triglycerides into the fatty acid and the glycerol. This is done primarily by another hormone called HSL, hormone-sensitive lipase. This process is regulated very finely by hormones, but it’s also dependent on substrate availability. Adrenaline and noradrenaline, which are acute stress hormones, promote this.

title: Fat Balance
content: The amount of fat you have in a fat cell is determined by the amount of calories you eat and the amount of calories you burn, and also by insulin levels. All of the amount of hormone in the world won’t change the fat, if you don’t have substrate availability. Similarly, the idea that just calorie balance alone makes this work is hard to explain empirically when you observe how easy it is to manipulate these things with endocrine systems.

title: Impact of Insulin in Lipolysis
content: A really important thing that insulin does when it’s elevated is it inhibits lipolysis, which plays a role in the positive fat flux scenario. And it’s a very non linear effect. At a very low level of insulin, there’s a high level of lipolysis. As insulin goes up, lipolysis just crashes. At some point, if insulin is high enough, you’re not getting any fat out of the fat cell.

title: Breaking the Hyperinsulinemic Cycle
content: There are lots of ways to break the hyperinsulinemic cycle: Carbohydrate restriction, Fasting, Fixing hypercortisolemia, Fixing sleep. Or, most likely, it’s a combination of all of the above.

title: Net Fat Efflux and Benefits of Fasting
content: A person whose fat cell is getting smaller, meaning they are in net fat efflux, i.e., “negative fat flux”. This is a person who is in a high state of lipolysis, which by definition, means they have low insulin. There is no faster way to get into this state than fasting. Nutritional ketosis is probably the fastest way to get into this state if you’re in a eucaloric state. After that, it’s going to be basically a complete fast and then various forms of caloric restriction.

title: Nutritional Strategies and Pharmacologic Approaches
content: Different nutritional strategies can be periodically revisited. There’s a whole suite of pharmacologic approaches to this. Some of them intuitive like metformin. Some of them counter-intuitive like GLP-1 agonists, which in the short run may actually raise insulin, but in the long run might actually lower postprandial insulin. Another option is something else like an SGLT2 inhibitor.

title: Exploring Fat Loss in Carbohydrate-Reduced or Ketogenic Diet
content: Most people with excess body fat will lose fat mass when reducing carbohydrates or eating a ketogenic diet. In the real world, many people who reduce carbohydrates end up eating less. But the more important question is, do they lose weight because they’re eating less or are they eating less because they are losing weight? It’s possible that as a person is changing the endocrine environment of their fat cell, they are liberating more free fatty acid & creating more substrate availability to the rest of the body. This could be that the body is saying, “Oh, come to think of it, I just don’t need to eat as much.”

title: Energy Expenditure and Internal Starvation Argument
content: Another subset of people may be increasing their energy expenditure when changing their diet. Some people as their nutritional state changes, they just feel better. They just have more energy and they become more active for whatever reason. They’re like, “Oh wow, I don’t feel the need to lay around in the afternoons.” Another endocrinologist, Edwin Astwood talked about “internal starvation”. If you see somebody who’s morbidly obese, it looks like that they probably can’t access that fat and they’re accumulating it. And if they can’t access it, they’re starving internally which means that they’re going to be hungrier and more lethargic because they literally have less energy to burn if it’s getting sequestered into the fat tissue.

title: Being in Nutritional Ketosis and Fat Loss
content: Being in nutritional ketosis does not automatically translate to negative fat flux (fat loss). If you go back to the equation, De novo lipogenesis (DNL) + re-esterification (RE) = lipolysis (L) — That’s what we call fat balance. If we want to be in negative fat flux, then L needs to be bigger than DNL + RE. Nothing about being in ketosis tells us the inputs to that equation. Ketosis just tells you that you are making a lot of BHB, beta-hydroxybutyrate. If you’re restricting carbohydrates and you’re not starving yourself, it means you’re eating a lot of fat. And one cannot tell by looking at this equation if L is bigger than, or less than, RE.

title: Troubleshooting Ketosis and Weight Loss
content: The best way to troubleshoot if you are in ketosis and not losing weight: Lower the fat intake. If you’ve clearly demonstrated that you’re in ketosis, then you’re working on the lipolysis side of the equation with all you can. The ketosis side of the equation implies insulin is low (which is great). You may just need to lower the re-esterification side by eating less fat.

title: Approach to Scientific Research
content: Starts very broad. First, try to triangulate onto, What’s the question that I’m trying to answer? With something like Omega-6, there’s so much information and it seems like there’s a pretty big debate on whether they’re actually helpful or they’re benign or they’re harmful. And he tries to gather as much information I can from those different camps on that question. First, he will look for the most recent review papers using Google Scholar and PubMed. He set parameters like only looking at review studies in the last, say three years, and see if anything pops up. If it does, I’ll give it a read.

title: Researching Limitations
content: Always tries to look at the limitations of a paper — gives credit to those that are honest about the limitations. An extensive list of limitations may be followed by a paragraph of how they totally controlled and adjusted for it.

title: Importance of Curiosity and Desire to Learn
content: Even those with backgrounds in science are constantly learning new things. Acknowledging that it's okay not to understand something and it might take a little longer to get through it, but having that sort of curiosity is the most important step to going through.

title: Tips and Tricks for Answering a Scientific Question in a Time-Crunch
content: When faced with a deadline to answer a complicated question, the process will depend on the question and topic and what knowledge has already been accumulated on said topics. In many cases, leaning on the network of people that has been created can be helpful. If an answer is needed fast, reaching out to somebody that a relationship has already been established with can be beneficial.

title: Understanding Vaccine Efficacy
content: The effect of vaccine is measured by comparing the risk reduction in the two groups of participants (vaccinated and placebo groups) in randomized clinical trials. Relative risk reduction (RRR) or commonly known as vaccine efficacy is often used to express the magnitude of this effect which is derived simply by subtracting the relative risk from one. Alternatively, absolute risk reduction (ARR) is rarely used but is a much more meaningful measurement of risk. ARR is difference between the risks of disease in the two populations and defines the absolute magnitude of the risk.

title: Online Resources for Learning
content: Ninja Nerd Lectures on YouTube, John Ioannidis, Vinay Prasad, Studying Studies series, Richard Feyman’s old lectures on YouTube are recommended for those with an insatiable curiosity about health and science.
